contents.context:
The South Korean government announced on Thursday plans to create a total of 1.five-six million jobs in the public sector, of which, around 765-thousand are new jobs.
The announcement comes just one day after figures showed the steepest job losses for the month of April in more than 20 years.

"The coronavirus outbreak is causing massive shocks and changes to the number and quality of jobs in the labor market, along with immediate job losses. Emergency employment measures are urgently needed."

The government expects some 765-thousand new jobs to be created.
It will resume the hiring process for some 48-thousand public officials and jobs in public institutions this month.
Young people directly hit by the pandemic will also have more opportunities through plans to create more than 550-thousand additional jobs in non-contact and digital sectors.
In the budget for this year, the government had planned to create 945-thousand jobs, and some 167-thousand of those will be added in May and June.
Officials plan to finalize the specific measures during next week's economic meeting, and draw up the required funds from a planned third coronavirus-related supplementary budget.
But an expert says more needs to be done to encourage hiring by private businesses.

"It's good that the government is drawing funds to create more jobs in the public sector. But it's more important to let private firms lead the economy, rather than the government taking the lead. The government could take extra measures, like reducing corporate taxes, leading companies to hire more and invest more."

"Both the public and private sectors will have to create jobs to overcome this employment crisis, but the government's measure can be seen as a positive step toward tackling the most torrid period that jobseekers have seen in years.
Kim Jae-hee, Arirang News."
Reporter : jhee@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Gov't to create total of 1.56 million public sector jobs: Finance Minister

contents.context:
The symbolic get-together between the heirs of Samsung Electronics and Hyundai Motor is fueling hopes for a profound parternship in smart mobility between the world's top chipmaker and the multinational carmaker.
The two are expected to have discussed possible cooperation in the electric vehicle business.
Other than government-sponsored events and meetings of business leaders, it was the first time that Samsung Group Vice Chairman Lee jae-yong and Hyundai Motor Group Executive Vice Chairman Chung Eui-sun to meet for business talks.
What does this mean for the nation's electric vehicle business and does it open up new opportunities? It's the topic of our News In-depth tonight with Yang Junsok, Professor of Economics at the Catholic University of Korea to my right and James P. Rooney, Vice Chairman for the Seoul Financial Forum to my left.

First of all, what is the significane of these two domestic powerhouses meeting?
Why is it important that these two heirs apparent of Korea's top conglomerates held a rare meeting?

Do you think the meeting was made possible because of the overall economic situation that Korea is in now because of COVID-19?

With the world becoming more environmentally-conscious, there seems to have been a growing demand for alternative energy vehicles, which of course includes these Battery Electric Vehicles. But with gas prices having dropped drastically amid the current pandemic, do you think the shift will be delayed? How do you think this affects the domestic vehicle purchasing habit?

Generally, it's common to think that battery operated, or even hybrid cars, have less power and are more expensive.
Sometimes, it's difficult to find charging stations, and even cases of weather affecting the batteries. Is this something of the past?
Why are you such a strong advocate of EVs? What are the advantages of EVs over engine vehicles?

President Moon Jae-in has been pushing for the Korean version of a New Deal not only create jobs but for Korea to lead the global digital economy. Earlier this week, he added a 'Green New Deal' to that.
How does the joining of Samsung and Hyundai to manufature EVs play into this plan?

Samsung Group has a car manufacturing line of their own. Why haven't they set out to produce EVs of their own? Why are they collaborating with Hyundai and supplying batteries?

Do you see South Korea becoming a stronger global BEV battery supplier or the next Tesla?

We saw in the past how a strong and demanding domestic market made Korea a world leader in ICE automobiles, flat screen TVs, refrigerators and air conditioning, and mobile phones and the high-technology components needed to support them.
What kind of support do we need in order to see similar results in new BEVs?

James P. Rooney, Vice Chairman for the Seoul Financial Forum and Yang Junsok, Professor of Economics at the Catholic University of Korea, many thanks as always for your insights.
We appreciate it.
Reporter : jenmoon@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
Samsung, Hyundai Heirs Discuss Electric Vehicle Cooperation

contents.context:
Online education has emerged as a promising sector for the post-COVID-19 economy.
With schools still closed and classes being held online, the industry is seeing an increase in demand.
And the sector is upgrading its services through new technologies.

"Online classes and lectures for young students and job-seekers have doubled compared to last year. We plan to provide students with a tailored curriculum using big data and AI technology."

IT companies are also gearing up to prepare for the post-pandemic era.
In fact, a number of IT firms in South Korea have seen demand for their services increase amid the coronavirus outbreak.
Those include non-face-to-face services, cloud computing and video conferencing.

"We are currently responding to an increase in demand for our non-face-to-face healthcare system due to COVID-19. This service is based on 'unified communication,' which combines cloud, security and network services."

In fact, Korea's IT giants posted an earnings surprise in the first quarter this year due to an increasing demand for non-contact services.
Naver Corporation has shown a strong performance on its online store and payment services, while Kakao Corporation has seen its sales jump thanks to mobile shopping and entertainment content.

"Because of the coronavirus, non-contact businesses will expand even after COVID-19, particularly those that are internet-based. It will be based on South Korea's strong IT infrastructure."

"As South Korea looks to strengthen its digital economy as part of the post-COVID-19 New Deal project, the IT industry could turn the health crisis into an opportunity.
Yoon Jung-min, Arirang News."
Reporter : yoonjm@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Online education, non-contact services booming in S. Korea

"Since April 22nd, the government has been rolling out stimulus packages to help the employment situation. As part of those measures, the government will focus on providing one.five-six million public sector jobs."

Some 600-thousand out of 945-thousand jobs including jobs for seniors in the public sector have not been active due to the epidemic, but the government will soon open up such jobs by easing some rules.

A study suggests that Korea raising the retirement age has resulted in fewer jobs for young people.
According to the state-run Korea Development Institute, for each person that continued to work after the age of 60, at small and medium-sized businesses, there were zero.2 fewer people employed between the ages of 15 and 29.
For big companies, with more than a thousand employees, the ratio was one to one.
The minimum age for retirement benefits was raised in 2016 to 60, which has encouraged people to stay on the job longer.
And KDI said that's made it harder for companies to take on new, younger employees.

Korean Air has suspended over 90 percent of its international flights since late March.

The UN World Economic Situation and Prospects report published Wednesday explained this would be the sharpest downturn since the Great Depression in the 1930s.

The report predicts a modest rebound next year, mostly making up for lost output.
